title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: ClinKit integrated R package designed transform cleaned clinical datasets directly publication-ready figures statistical outputs, preserving access raw analysis objects complete methodological transparency customization. tailored clinical research workflows, providing one-stop solution routine statistical analysis reporting.

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: can install development version ClinKit GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("LeafLight/ClinKit")

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: demonstration, use simulated dataset:
code: library(ClinKit) set.seed(123) data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 50),   age = rnorm(100, 60, 10),   gender = sample(c("Male", "Female"), 100, replace = TRUE),   outcome = rbinom(100, 1, 0.4) ) head(data)

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: Generate baseline characteristics table automatic test selection:
code: result <- make_baseline_table(data, group_var = "group") print(result$summary) # Export to Word gtsummary::as_flextable(result$summary) |> flextable::save_as_docx(path = "baseline_table.docx")

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: uni_res <- run_univariate_logistic_regression(data, outcome = "outcome", predictors = c("age", "gender")) print(uni_res$summary)

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: multi_res <- run_multivariable_logistic_regression(data, outcome = "outcome", predictors = c("age", "gender"), covariates = c("group")) print(multi_res$summary)

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: scatter_lm(data, x = "age", y = "outcome")

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: # Example: subgroup_forest # (Assume you have a suitable regression result) # subgroup_forest(model_result, subgroup_var = "gender")

code: # highlow_analysis(data, outcome = "outcome", exposure1 = "age", exposure2 = "group")

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: # quartile_logistic_analysis(data, outcome = "outcome", predictor = "age")

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
code: # roc_analysis(data, outcome = "outcome", predictors = c("age", "group"))

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: Tables can exported Word (.docx) CSV. Figures can saved PNG, PDF, SVG.

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: functions return raw analysis objects customization. Supports integration tidyverse workflows. Publication-ready outputs minimal code.

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: ClinKit streamlines process clinical data analysis reporting R, making accessible, reproducible, publication-ready. details, visit ClinKit documentation website.

title: ClinKit: Streamlined Clinical Data Analysis in R
text: ClinKit GitHub gtsummary pkgdown

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hualin Wang. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wang H (2025). ClinKit: Package (One Line, Title Case). R package version 0.0.0.9, https://github.com/leaflight/ClinKit.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ClinKit: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)},   author = {Hualin Wang},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9},   url = {https://github.com/leaflight/ClinKit}, }

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: ClinKit integrated R package designed transform cleaned clinical datasets directly publication-ready figures statistical outputs, preserving access raw analysis objects complete methodological transparency customization.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can install development version ClinKit GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("LeafLight/ClinKit")

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: minimal example using built-example data:
code: library(ClinKit) # Example: Generate a baseline table data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 50),   age = rnorm(100, 60, 10),   gender = sample(c("Male", "Female"), 100, replace = TRUE) ) result <- make_baseline_table(data, group_var = "group") print(result$summary) # Export to Word gtsummary::as_flextable(result$summary) |> flextable::save_as_docx(path = "baseline_table.docx")

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: make_baseline_table(): Automated baseline characteristic tables intelligent test selection. Wraps gtsummary::tbl_summary() built-normality testing automatically choose appropriate parametric non-parametric tests, exporting directly formatted Word documents. run_univariate_logistic_regression(): Single predictor analysis run_multivariable_logistic_regression(): Sequential multivariable models (Model 1-4) incremental covariate adjustment run_multivariable_multinomial_logistic_regression(): Multi-category outcome analysis scatter_lm(): Clean scatter plots linear regression scatter_lm_marginal(): Enhanced versions marginal distributions subgroup_forest(): Publication-ready forest plots 4 built-themes comprehensive p-value reporting highlow_analysis(): Variable interaction analysis intuitive high/low grouping quartile_logistic_analysis(), quartile_multinomial_analysis(): Streamlined quartile-based analysis (Q1-Q4) continuous predictors roc_analysis(): ROC curve visualization tidy DeLong test results

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Progressive Modeling: Sequential multivariable regression incremental covariate adjustment (Models 1-4) Reproducible Research: functions return raw analysis objects alongside formatted outputs Methodological Rigor: Automated statistical appropriateness checks Publication-Ready: Direct export journal-compatible formats Clinical Focus: Specialized methods common clinical research scenarios

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: ClinKit depends several R packages, including gtsummary, flextable, ggplot2, others. dependencies installed automatically.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can use cleaned clinical dataset, refer example usage section .

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Contributions, bug reports, feature requests welcome! Please open issue submit pull request GitHub.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: questions support, please contact LeafLight open issue GitHub repository.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: project licensed MIT License. See LICENSE file details.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: ClinKit Documents

text: data Data frame vars Character vector, names indicator variables plot groupby Character scalar, name grouping variable

text: ggplot object

title: Faceted Violin Plot — facet_violin
text: function : Select specified columns convert long format Convert grouping variable factor Draw violin plots boxplots inside, faceted indicator

title: Faceted Violin Plot — facet_violin
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- facet_violin(iris, c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width"), "Species") print(p) } # }

what: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value
title: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value
text: Returns p-values common journal formats: p < 0.001  →  "name < 0.001" 0.001 ≤ p < 0.01  →  scientific notation (×10⁻ⁿ) p ≥ 0.01  →  keep 3 decimal places Outputs plotmath expressions can directly used ggplot2::annotate() ggpmisc::stat_poly_eq() label parameters.

title: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value
code: format_p_value(p, name)

title: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value
text: p Numeric vector, p-values format (typically 0-1) name Character scalar, p-value prefix, e.g., "p", "P interaction", "P trend"

title: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value
code: Character vector, valid \code{plotmath} expressions, e.g.,         \code{"p < 0.001"}, \code{"p~\"=\"~3.14\times10^{-4}"},         \code{"p~\"=\"~0.03"}

title: Format p-value as plotmath expression string — format_p_value

what: Generate Background Levels for Forest Plot (Internal) — generate_background_levels
title: Generate Background Levels for Forest Plot (Internal) — generate_background_levels
text: Creates background level vector based data structure: First row: level 1 (Title) Rows NA : level 3 (Subgroup Title) rows: alternating 1 2 (row data)

title: Generate Background Levels for Forest Plot (Internal) — generate_background_levels
code: generate_background_levels(forest_data)

title: Generate Background Levels for Forest Plot (Internal) — generate_background_levels
text: forest_data Data frame subgroup analysis

title: Generate Background Levels for Forest Plot (Internal) — generate_background_levels
text: Numeric vector background levels

title: Restricted Cubic Splines (RCS) Logistic Regression with Plot — generate_rcs_plot
text: Fits RCS logistic regression models generates publication-ready plots

title: Restricted Cubic Splines (RCS) Logistic Regression with Plot — generate_rcs_plot
code: generate_rcs_plot(   data,   outcome,   predictor,   covariates = NULL,   knots = 4,   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "tiff", "svg", "pdf", "all"),   filename = NULL )

title: Restricted Cubic Splines (RCS) Logistic Regression with Plot — generate_rcs_plot
text: data Data frame containing variables outcome Outcome variable name predictor Continuous predictor variable name RCS covariates Covariates adjusted model (optional) knots Number knots RCS (default 4) output_dir Output directory (optional) save_format Save format: "none", "tiff", "svg", "pdf", "" (default "none") filename Custom filename prefix (optional)

title: Restricted Cubic Splines (RCS) Logistic Regression with Plot — generate_rcs_plot
text: List containing plot object, p-values, optional saved file paths

what: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
title: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
text: Provides several predefined color themes forest plots Times New Roman font.

title: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
code: get_forest_theme(   theme_name = c("blue", "green", "cyan", "default"),   base_size = 12,   background_levels = NULL )  tm_blue(base_size = 12, background_levels = NULL)  tm_green(base_size = 12, background_levels = NULL)  tm_cyan(base_size = 12, background_levels = NULL)  tm_default(base_size = 12, background_levels = NULL)

title: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
text: theme_name Theme name: "blue", "green", "cyan", "default" base_size Base font size, default 12 background_levels Background color levels vector subgroup hierarchy

title: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
text: Forest plot theme object

title: Get Predefined Forest Plot Themes — get_forest_theme
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ tm <- get_forest_theme("blue") result <- subgroup_forest(..., tm = tm) } # }

what: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
title: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
text: Analyzes joint effects two continuous exposures median dichotomization, creating four exposure groups fitting logistic regression models sequential covariate adjustment. Calculates additive interaction measures.

title: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
code: highlow_analysis(   data,   outcome,   exposure_a,   exposure_b,   model2 = NULL,   model3 = NULL,   model4 = NULL,   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "docx", "all"),   recode = FALSE,   filename_base = "highlow_analysis" )

title: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
text: data Data frame containing outcome, exposures covariates outcome Character scalar, binary outcome variable name (0/1) exposure_a Character scalar, continuous exposure variable name exposure_b Character scalar, continuous exposure B variable name model2 Character vector, additional covariates model 2 model3 Character vector, additional covariates model 3 model4 Character vector, additional covariates model 4 output_dir Output directory saving results, default NULL save_format Save format: "none", "docx", "", default "none" recode Logical, whether recode interaction variables, default FALSE filename_base Base filename outputs, default "highlow_analysis"

title: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
text: List containing analysis results, interaction measures, optional saved file paths

title: High-High vs Low-Low Four-Group Logistic Regression with Additive Interaction — highlow_analysis
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ result <- highlow_analysis(   data = mtcars,   outcome = "vs",   exposure_a = "mpg",   exposure_b = "wt",   model2 = c("cyl", "gear"),   model3 = c("carb"),   output_dir = tempdir(),   save_format = "all" ) } # }

text: Check groups variable normal

title: Check if all groups for a variable are normal — is_normal_overall
code: is_normal_overall(normality_results, var)

title: Check if all groups for a variable are normal — is_normal_overall
text: normality_results Data frame perform_normality_tests var Character, variable name check

title: Check if all groups for a variable are normal — is_normal_overall
text: Logical, TRUE groups normal, FALSE otherwise

what: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
text: Automatically generates baseline characteristics table counts (percentages) categorical variables appropriate statistics continuous variables based normality testing. Outputs three-line table Word format P-values Overall column.

title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
code: make_baseline_table(   data,   outcome,   vars = NULL,   file,   pct_digits = 2,   cont_digits = 2,   p_digits = 3,   label_list = NULL,   normality_test_method = "shapiro",   normality_alpha = 0.05,   export_normality = TRUE,   normality_file = NULL )

title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
text: data Data frame containing grouping variable variables summarize outcome Character scalar, grouping variable name (typically binary factor) vars Character vector, variables display; NULL (default) displays variables except outcome file Character, output Word file name (path); parent directory must exist pct_digits Decimal places percentages, default 2 cont_digits Decimal places continuous variables, default 2 p_digits Decimal places P-values, default 3 label_list Named list, variable labels, e.g., list(age = "Age (years)"); NULL, uses original column names normality_test_method Character, method normality test ("shapiro" "ks"), default "shapiro" normality_alpha Numeric, significance level normality test, default 0.05 export_normality Logical, whether export normality test results separate CSV file, default TRUE normality_file Character, output CSV file name normality test results; NULL, uses base name main file

title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
text: gtsummary object (invisible), convenient subsequent piping operations

title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
text: Categorical variables displayed n(%) Continuous variables: groups normal, display mean (SD); otherwise display median (Q1, Q3) Missing values displayed default; P-values use appropriate tests (chi-square/t/ANOVA/Kruskal-Wallis) Final table exported via flextable, ready use papers appendices Normality test results can exported CSV reference

title: One-Click Baseline Characteristics Table (gtsummary version) — make_baseline_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ make_baseline_table(   data     = mydata,   outcome  = "Group",   vars     = c("age", "sex", "smoke", "sbp"),   file     = "Table1_Baseline.docx",   label_list = list(age = "Age (years)", sbp = "Systolic BP (mmHg)") ) } # }

text: raw_df Results data frame multivariable analysis out_file Output Word file path (optional) caption Table caption merge_predictor Merge identical predictor cells vertically (default TRUE)

title: Create Multivariate Analysis Table — make_multivariate_table

title: Quartile-based Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_logistic_analysis
text: Analyzes continuous predictors quartile groups, fitting: Model1 (unadjusted) Model2/3/4 (sequentially adding covariates) Calculates , 95% CI Q2/Q3/Q4 vs Q1 trend P-value.

title: Quartile-based Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_logistic_analysis
code: quartile_logistic_analysis(   data,   outcomes,   predictors,   models_list,   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "docx", "csv", "all") )

title: Quartile-based Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_logistic_analysis
text: data Data frame containing variables outcomes Character vector binary outcome variable names predictors Character vector continuous predictor variable names models_list Named list length 3 covariates model2, model3, model4 output_dir Output directory (optional) save_format Save format: "none", "docx", "csv", "" (default "none")

title: Quartile-based Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_logistic_analysis
text: List containing results data frame optional saved file paths

title: Quartile-based Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_logistic_analysis
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ models_list <- list(   model2 = c("cyl", "gear"),   model3 = c("carb"),   model4 = c("hp") )  result <- quartile_logistic_analysis(   data = mtcars,   outcomes = "vs",   predictors = c("mpg", "wt"),   models_list = models_list ) } # }

what: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
title: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
text: Analyzes continuous predictors quartile groups multinomial outcomes, fitting multiple models sequential covariate adjustment.

title: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
code: quartile_multinomial_analysis(   data,   outcomes,   predictors,   models_list,   ref_level = NULL,   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "docx", "csv", "all") )

title: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
text: data Data frame containing variables outcomes Character vector multinomial outcome variable names predictors Character vector continuous predictor variable names models_list Named list covariates different models ref_level Reference level multinomial outcome (optional) output_dir Output directory (optional) save_format Save format: "none", "docx", "csv", "" (default "none")

title: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
text: List containing results data frame optional saved file paths

title: Quartile-based Multinomial Logistic Regression Analysis — quartile_multinomial_analysis
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create test data with multinomial outcome set.seed(123) test_data <- data.frame(   outcome = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 100, replace = TRUE),   predictor1 = rnorm(100),   predictor2 = rnorm(100),   cov1 = rnorm(100),   cov2 = sample(c("X", "Y"), 100, replace = TRUE) )  models_list <- list(   model2 = c("cov1"),   model3 = c("cov1", "cov2") )  result <- quartile_multinomial_analysis(   data = test_data,   outcomes = "outcome",   predictors = c("predictor1", "predictor2"),   models_list = models_list,   output_dir = tempdir(),   save_format = "all" ) } # }

what: ROC Curve Analysis with AUC Comparison and Optimal Cutoff — roc_analysis
title: ROC Curve Analysis with AUC Comparison and Optimal Cutoff — roc_analysis
text: Performs comprehensive ROC analysis single multiple continuous indicators custom combination models, including AUC calculation, optimal cutoff determination, DeLong test AUC comparisons.

title: ROC Curve Analysis with AUC Comparison and Optimal Cutoff — roc_analysis
code: roc_analysis(   data,   outcome,   predictors,   combined_models = NULL,   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "plot", "data", "all"),   delong_test = FALSE,   colors = NULL,   legend_labels = NULL,   seed = 123,   plot_width = 2000,   plot_height = 2000,   plot_res = 300,   direction = "<" )

title: ROC Curve Analysis with AUC Comparison and Optimal Cutoff — roc_analysis
text: data Data frame containing outcome predictor variables outcome Character scalar, binary outcome variable name (0/1) predictors Character vector, continuous predictor variable names combined_models Named list combined models, e.g., list(Combined = c("X1", "X2")) output_dir Output directory saving results, default NULL save_format Save format: "none", "plot", "data", "", default "none" delong_test Logical, whether perform DeLong test pairwise AUC comparisons, default FALSE colors Custom color vector ROC curves; NULL, colors automatically sampled legend_labels Named vector custom legend labels, e.g., c(PIV = "Systemic Inflammation Index") seed Random seed reproducibility, default 123 plot_width Plot width pixels, default 2000 plot_height Plot height pixels, default 2000 plot_res Plot resolution DPI, default 300 direction roc direction, "auto" automatic selection, default <

title: ROC Curve Analysis with AUC Comparison and Optimal Cutoff — roc_analysis
text: List containing ROC objects, AUC summary, optional saved file paths

code: save_quartile_table(results, file_path)

what: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
text: Quickly draws X-Y scatter plot linear regression confidence band, annotates R^2 P value within plot; Supports rug plots additional aesthetic parameters points

title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
code: scatter_lm(data, x, y, digits = 3, label.x = NULL, label.y = NULL, ...)

title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
text: data data.frame, must contain x y columns x, y Character scalars, variable names digits Numeric, decimal places R^2 P value, default 3 label.x, label.y Coordinates annotation; NULL, automatically placed top-left 5% position ... Additional parameters passed geom_point() geom_rug(), e.g., color = group, size = 2, alpha = 0.6

title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
code: \code{ggplot} object, can be further customized with \code{+} or saved

title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
text: Uses lm(y ~ x) fitting draws 95% confidence band Rug plots bottom left jitter avoid overlap Annotation text uses Times font consistent theming

title: Scatter Plot with Regression Line (Basic Version) — scatter_lm
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- scatter_lm(mtcars, "wt", "mpg",                 color = cyl, size = 3, alpha = 0.7) print(p) ggsave("scatter_lm.png", p, width = 5, height = 4) } # }

what: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
text: Main plot: scatter points + linear regression line + automatic annotation equation, R^2, p value (ggpmisc::stat_poly_eq). Marginal plots: bilateral densigram (density + histogram mix), supports grouping colors. Color logic: uniform color color grouping; automatic coloring group variable hidden legend color specified.

title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
code: scatter_lm_marginal(   data,   x,   y,   digits = 3,   label.x = NULL,   label.y = NULL,   color = NULL,   marginal = c("histogram", "density", "boxplot"),   bins = 15,   margin_fill = "grey60",   margin_color = "white",   ... )

title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
text: data Data frame, must contain x, y optional color grouping variable x, y Character scalars, variable names digits Decimal places equation/statistics, default 3 (controlled stat_poly_eq) label.x, label.y Deprecated, kept backward compatibility color Character scalar, grouping variable name; NULL grouping marginal Marginal plot type, fixed "densigram" bins Number histogram bins, passed ggExtra::ggMarginal margin_fill, margin_color Fill color border color marginal plots ... Additional aesthetic parameters passed geom_point()

title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
code: ggplot object (with marginal layers), can be further customized with + or saved

title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
text: Uses ggpmisc::stat_poly_line() + stat_poly_eq() automatically add regression line equation Marginal plots densigram (density + histogram), supports group colors/fill Uniform color #479E88 grouping; uses scale_color_npg() hidden legend grouping Returned object already includes marginal layers, can directly saved ggsave()

title: Scatter Plot with Marginal Density/Histogram and Regression Equation (Enhanced Version) — scatter_lm_marginal
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- scatter_lm_marginal(mtcars, "wt", "mpg", color = "cyl", bins = 20) print(p) ggsave("scatter_marginal.png", p, width = 6, height = 5) } # }

what: Setup Font Configuration for Math Symbols (Internal) — setup_font_config
title: Setup Font Configuration for Math Symbols (Internal) — setup_font_config
text: Setup Font Configuration Math Symbols (Internal)

title: Setup Font Configuration for Math Symbols (Internal) — setup_font_config
code: setup_font_config(math_font = NULL, ensure_italic_p = TRUE)

what: Forest Plot for Subgroup Analysis — subgroup_forest
title: Forest Plot for Subgroup Analysis — subgroup_forest
text: Fits generalized linear models specified exposure variable outcome calculates effect sizes (default ) 95% CI, P-values, sample proportions within multiple subgroups. Returns formatted data forest plot.

title: Forest Plot for Subgroup Analysis — subgroup_forest
code: subgroup_forest(   data,   outcome,   exposure,   subgroups,   covariates = NULL,   family = "binomial",   output_dir = NULL,   save_format = c("none", "data", "plot", "all"),   decimal_estimate = 2,   decimal_pvalue = 3,   line = FALSE,   prepare_plot = TRUE,   tm = "blue",   xlim = NULL,   ticks_at = NULL,   plot_title = "Forest Plot of Subgroup Analysis",   xlab = "Odds Ratio",   CI_title = "OR(95%CI)",   math_font = NULL,   ensure_italic_p = TRUE )

title: Forest Plot for Subgroup Analysis — subgroup_forest
text: data Data frame containing outcome, exposure subgroup/covariate variables outcome Character scalar, outcome variable name exposure Character scalar, exposure variable name (main effect) subgroups Character vector, subgroup variable names covariates Character vector, additional covariates, default NULL family GLM family, default "binomial"; can "gaussian" etc. output_dir Output directory saving results, default NULL save_format Save format: "none", "data", "plot", "", default "none" decimal_estimate Decimal places effect estimates, default 2 decimal_pvalue Decimal places P-values, default 3 line Logical, whether draw separation lines subgroups, default FALSE prepare_plot Logical, whether prepare data forestploter, default TRUE tm Forest plot theme, default "blue", can alse choose green, cyan passing custom theme forestploter::forest_theme xlim xlim forest plot, default NULL ticks_at numeric vector specify x tick forestplot plot_title Plot title, default "Forest Plot Subgroup Analysis" xlab X-axis label, default "Odds Ratio" CI_title title Confidence Interval, default "(95%CI)" math_font font want use display math charactor(included normal fonts) ensure_italic_p TRUE want use italic p

title: Forest Plot for Subgroup Analysis — subgroup_forest
text: List containing forest plot data, plot object, optional saved file paths
